query: My care needs assessment in liverpool says I need 20 hours of home care weekly, but I'm worried about costs. What financial help is available?

retrieved_documents.content: . Do I need to pay for care at home? We will arrange a financial assessment to see if you need to pay, and how much. We will check you are getting all benefits that you are entitled to. See paying for care and support at home for more information . Further help If you don't qualify for a care package you can employ a care worker through a private agency. Be careful to choose an agency registered and inspected by the Care Quality Commission . You can also visit the Live Well Directory , which provides information about other care and support services available in Liverpool. in the city to choose from. If you choose an agency that charges more than the 
council’s standard hourly rate it is your responsibility to pay the difference in cost

. A deferred payment agreement is another option if you do not wish to sell your home yet. If you think you are going to have support needs, the law says you must not give away your money or property to avoid or reduce paying for care. If we think you have done this, it will still be counted in your financial assessment. If you are a self-funder (paying for your own care) with savings over £23,250 you will need to make arrangements to pay the care home directly. A private arrangement between you and the care home means that the weekly rate will be different to the council contracted rate. Care home top-up fees If we are funding your care home place, we will allocate an amount of money to meet your  needs following the financial assessment. If you choose a home that is more expensive than the amount we can fund, you can still move there as long as someone, such as another family member agrees to pay the difference or the ‘top-up fee’

Residential homes All residential homes in Liverpool are run privately. The council no longer runs any residential homes. Types of residential home There are two types of residential home: Care homes have trained staff offering similar care to that you would receive from relatives and friends in your own home. Nursing homes provide the same level of care as care homes but also have trained nurses on duty to provide nursing care when you need it. I am thinking of moving into a residential home If you or someone you care for is thinking about making a residential home your permanent place of residence, complete an adult social care assessment . If you are already known to us and receive support services at home, we can arrange a review of your needs. If you are not already known to us and do not receive support services at home we will arrange a full care needs assessment. In both instances, we can talk you through the assessment process and how to choose a home

Paying for care homes If your care needs assessment has identified that a care home or nursing home (residential care) is the best way to meet your needs, we may ask you to pay a contribution towards the cost. A financial assessment will look at your money to see how much you can afford to pay towards your care each week. If this amount is not enough, you may qualify for help to pay. You will not qualify for help to pay if: the financial assessment shows you can afford to pay for all of your care you choose to arrange your care privately you choose not to have a financial assessment or do not give us all the information we need You'll be offered a benefit check by a member of the Benefits Maximisation Service , who will make sure you are receiving all the benefits you are entitled to. What we look at When we look at how much money you have, there are some things we ignore and some things we include. If we ignore something, we do not expect you to use it to pay for care and will not assess it

. You can also ask for a 'loan-style DPA' secured against your home. This is where the council loans you the money for your residential care placement. You can ask us for further information about this scheme during your assessment. How much will it cost? We will charge a fixed fee of £450 to set up a DPA and an annual fee of £144 for ongoing administration costs whilst the DPA is in place. Interest will also be charged on the outstanding debt. The maximum interest rate to be charged is fixed by the government and is reviewed on 1st January and 1st July each year. Currently it is 4.65 per cent, as of 1st July 2025. You can pay the set-up and annual fees as and when they are charged, or add them to the amount you will eventually repay. All fees relate to the cost to Liverpool City Council for administering a DPA only and are subject to review at any time. Who is eligible? You should be eligible for a DPA if you: Are receiving care in a care home or nursing home, or you are going to move into one soon

answer:
If you are concerned about the costs of your home care in Liverpool, you may be eligible for financial assistance through a financial assessment conducted by the Liverpool City Council. This assessment will determine how much you need to contribute towards your care and ensure you are receiving all the benefits you are entitled to.

**Key Points:**
- **Financial Assessment:** Liverpool City Council will perform a financial assessment to determine your contribution towards the cost of your care. This assessment will consider your income and expenditure.
- **Benefits Maximisation:** As part of the assessment, you will be offered a benefits maximisation check to ensure you are receiving all the benefits you are entitled to. This service is free.
- **Direct Payments:** If you choose to use a private agency for your care, you may receive direct payments to cover the cost. However, if the agency charges more than the council’s standard rate, you will need to pay the difference.

**Next Steps:**
- Visit the [Liverpool City Council's Adult Social Care page](https://www.liverpool.gov.uk/adult-social-care/who-we-support/living-independently/care-at-home/) for more information on financial assessments and available support.
- Contact Liverpool City Council to arrange a financial assessment and discuss your specific situation.

By following these steps, you can better understand your financial obligations and explore potential support options for your home care needs.
